1.verse: Here Comes the Sequel! - Dear Theophilus, The previous book which I wrote had to do with everything Jesus began to do and teach.

2.verse: I took the story as far as the day when he was taken up, once he had given instructions through the holy spirit to his chosen apostles.

3.verse: He showed himself to them alive, after his suffering, by many proofs. He was seen by them for forty days, during which he spoke about God’s kingdom.

4.verse: As they were having a meal together, he told them not to go away from Jerusalem, but to wait, as he put it, ‘for the father’s promise, which I was telling you about earlier.

5.verse: John baptized with water, you see; but in a few days from now you will be baptized with the holy spirit.’

6.verse: When, What and How? - So when the apostles came together, they put this question to Jesus. ‘Master,’ they said, ‘is this the time when you are going to restore the kingdom to Israel?’

7.verse: ‘It’s not your business to know about times and dates,’ he replied. ‘The father has placed all that under his own direct authority.

8.verse: What will happen, though, is that you will receive power when the holy spirit comes upon you. Then you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, in all Judaea and Samaria, and to the very ends of the earth.’

9.verse: Ascension! - As Jesus said this, he was lifted up while they were watching, and a cloud took him out of their sight.

10.verse: They were gazing into heaven as he disappeared. Then, lo and behold, two men appeared, dressed in white, standing beside them.

11.verse: ‘Galileans,’ they said, ‘why are you standing here staring into heaven? This Jesus, who has been taken from you into heaven, will come back in the same way you saw him go into heaven.’

12.verse: Then they went back to Jerusalem from the hill called the Mount of Olives, which is close to Jerusalem, about the distance you could travel on a sabbath.

13.verse: They then entered the city (‘they’ here means Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James the son of Alphaeus, Simon the zealot, and Judas the son of James) and went to the upstairs room where they were staying.

14.verse: They all gave themselves single-heartedly to prayer, with the women, including Mary, Jesus’ mother, and his brothers.

15.verse: Restoring the Twelve - Around that time Peter stood up in the middle of the gathering, which by this stage numbered about a hundred and twenty.

16.verse: ‘My dear family,’ he said, ‘the holy spirit spoke long ago, through the mouth of David, about Judas, who became a guide to the people who arrested Jesus. There it is in the Bible, and it had to come true.

17.verse: He was counted along with us, and he had his own share in the work we’ve been given.’

18.verse: ( Judas, you see, had bought a field with the money his wickedness had brought him, where he fell headlong and burst open, with all his innards gushing out.

19.verse: This became known to everyone who lived in Jerusalem, so that the field was called, in their local language, ‘Akeldamach’, which means ‘Blood-place’.)

20.verse: ‘For this is what it says in the book of the Psalms: Let his home become desolate and let nobody live in it. and again Let someone else receive his overseeing task.

21.verse: ‘So this is what has to be done. There are plenty of people who have gone about with us all the time that our master Jesus was coming and going among us,

22.verse: starting from John’s baptism until the day he was taken from us. Let one of them be chosen to be alongside us as a special witness of his resurrection.’

23.verse: So they chose two: Joseph who was called Barsabbas, with the surname Justus, and Matthias.

24.verse: ‘Lord,’ they prayed, ‘you know the hearts of all people. Show us which one of these two you have chosen

25.verse: to receive this particular place of service and apostleship, from which Judas went away to go to his own place.’

26.verse: So they cast lots for them. The lot fell on Matthias, and he was enrolled along with the eleven apostles.

1.verse: Here Comes the Power - When the day of Pentecost had finally arrived, they were all together in the same place.

2.verse: Suddenly there came from heaven a noise like the sound of a strong, blowing wind, and it filled the whole house where they were sitting.

3.verse: Then tongues, seemingly made of fire, appeared to them, moving apart and coming to rest on each one of them.

4.verse: They were all filled with the holy spirit, and began to speak in other languages, as the spirit gave them the words to say.

5.verse: New Words for New News - There were devout Jews from every nation under heaven staying in Jerusalem at that time.

6.verse: When they heard this noise they came together in a crowd. They were deeply puzzled, because every single one of them could hear them speaking in his or her own native language.

7.verse: They were astonished and amazed. ‘These men who are doing the speaking are all Galileans, aren’t they?’ they said.

8.verse: ‘So how is it that each of us can hear them in our own mother tongues?

9.verse: There are Parthians here, and Medians, Elamites, people from Mesopotamia, Judaea, Cappadocia, Pontus, Asia,

10.verse: Phrygia and Pamphylia, Egypt and the parts of Libya that belong to Cyrene; there are people from Rome,

11.verse: proselytes as well as Jews; there are Cretans and Arabs. We can hear them telling us about the powerful things God has done – in our own languages!’

12.verse: Everyone was astonished and perplexed. ‘What does it all mean?’ they were asking each other.

13.verse: But some sneered. ‘They’re full of new wine!’ they said.

14.verse: It’s All Coming True at Last! - Then Peter got up, with the eleven. He spoke to them in a loud voice. ‘People of Judaea!’ he began. ‘All of you staying here in Jerusalem! There’s something you have to know! Listen to what I’m saying!

15.verse: These people aren’t drunk, as you imagine. It’s only nine o’clock in the morning!

16.verse: No, this is what the prophet Joel was talking about, when he said,

17.verse: In the last days, declares God, I will pour out my spirit on all people. Your sons and your daughters will prophesy; your young men will see visions, your old men will dream dreams;

18.verse: yes, even on slaves, men and women alike, will I pour out my spirit in those days, and they shall prophesy.

19.verse: And I will give signs in the heavens above, and portents on earth beneath, blood and fire and clouds of smoke.

20.verse: The sun will be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the day of the Lord comes, the great and glorious day.

21.verse: And then everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.

22.verse: David Speaks of Jesus’ Resurrection - ‘You people of Israel,’ Peter continued, ‘listen to this. Jesus of Nazareth was a man marked out for you by God through the mighty works, signs and portents which God performed through him right here among you, as you all know.

23.verse: He was handed over in accordance with God’s determined purpose and foreknowledge – and you used people outside the law to nail him up and kill him.

24.verse: ‘But God raised him from the dead! Death had its painful grip on him; but God released him from it, because it wasn’t possible for him to be mastered by it.

25.verse: This, you see, is how David speaks of him: I set the Lord before me always; because he is at my right hand, I won’t be shaken.

26.verse: So my heart was happy, and my tongue rejoiced, and my flesh, too, will rest in hope.

27.verse: For you will not leave my soul in Hades, nor will you allow your Holy One to see corruption.

28.verse: You showed me the path of life, you filled me with gladness in your presence.

29.verse: ‘My dear family, I can surely speak freely to you about the patriarch David. He died and was buried, and his tomb is here with us to this day.

30.verse: He was of course a prophet, and he knew that God had sworn an oath to him to set one of his own physical offspring on his throne.

31.verse: He foresaw the Messiah’s resurrection, and spoke about him ‘not being left in Hades’, and about his flesh ‘not seeing corruption’.

32.verse: This is the Jesus we’re talking about! God raised him from the dead, and all of us here are witnesses to the fact!

33.verse: Now he’s been exalted to God’s right hand; and what you see and hear is the result of the fact that he is pouring out the holy spirit, which had been promised, and which he has received from the father.

34.verse: ‘David, after all, did not ascend into the heavens. This is what he says: The Lord said to my Lord, sit at my right hand,

35.verse: until I place your enemies underneath your feet.

36.verse: ‘So the whole house of Israel must know this for a fact: God has made him Lord and Messiah – this Jesus, the one you crucified.’

37.verse: God’s Rescue Plan - When they heard this, the people in the crowd were cut to the heart. ‘Brothers,’ they said to Peter and the other apostles, ‘what shall we do?’

38.verse: ‘Turn back!’ replied Peter. ‘Be baptized – every single one of you – in the name of Jesus the Messiah, so that your sins can be forgiven, and you will receive the gift of the holy spirit.

39.verse: The promise is for you and for your children, and for everyone who is far away, as many as the Lord our God will call.’

40.verse: He carried on explaining things to them with many other words. ‘Let God rescue you’, he was urging them, ‘from this wicked generation!’

41.verse: Those who welcomed his word were baptized. About three thousand people were added to the community that day.

42.verse: The New Family - They all gave full attention to the teaching of the apostles and to the common life, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.

43.verse: Great awe fell on everyone, and many remarkable deeds and signs were performed by the apostles.

44.verse: All of those who believed came together, and held everything in common.

45.verse: They sold their possessions and belongings and divided them up to everyone in proportion to their various needs.

46.verse: Day by day they were all together attending the Temple. They broke bread in their various houses, and ate their food with glad and sincere hearts,

47.verse: praising God and standing in favour with all the people. And every day the Lord added to their number those who were being rescued.

1.verse: More than He Bargained for - One day, Peter and John were going up to the Temple at three o’clock in the afternoon, the time for prayer.

2.verse: There was a man being carried in who had been lame since birth. People used to bring him every day to the Temple gate called ‘Beautiful’, so that he could ask for alms from folk on their way in to the Temple.

3.verse: When he saw Peter and John going in to the Temple, he asked them to give him some money.

4.verse: Peter, with John, looked hard at him. ‘Look at us,’ he said.

5.verse: The man stared at them, expecting to get something from them.

6.verse: ‘I haven’t got any silver or gold’, Peter said, ‘but I’ll give you what I have got. In the name of the Messiah, Jesus of Nazareth, get up and walk!’

7.verse: He grabbed the man by his right hand and lifted him up. At once his feet and ankles became strong,

8.verse: and he leaped to his feet and began to walk. He went in with them into the Temple, walking and jumping up and down and praising God.

9.verse: All the people saw him walking and praising God,

10.verse: and they recognized him as the man who had been sitting begging for alms by the Beautiful Gate of the Temple. They were filled with amazement and astonishment at what had happened to him.

11.verse: An Explanation is Called for - All the people ran together in astonishment towards Peter and John, and the man who was clinging onto them. They were in the part of the Temple known as ‘Solomon’s Porch’.

12.verse: Peter saw them all and began to speak. ‘Fellow Israelites,’ he said, ‘why are you amazed at this? Why are you staring at us as though it was our own power or piety that made this man walk?

13.verse: “The God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, the God of Jacob – the God of our ancestors” – he has glorified his child Jesus, the one you handed over and denied in the presence of Pilate, although he had decided to let him go.

14.verse: But you denied the Holy One, the Just One, and requested instead to have a murderer given to you;

15.verse: and so you killed the Prince of Life. But God raised him from the dead, and we are witnesses to the fact.

16.verse: And it is his name, working through faith in his name, that has given strength to this man, whom you see and know. It is faith which comes through him that has given him this new complete wholeness in front of all of you.’

17.verse: Restoration and Refreshment - ‘Now, my dear family,’ Peter continued, ‘I know that you acted in ignorance, just as your rulers did.

18.verse: But this is how God has fulfilled what he promised through the mouth of all the prophets, that his Messiah would suffer.

19.verse: So now repent, and turn back, so that your sins may be blotted out,

20.verse: so that times of refreshment may come from the presence of the Lord, and so that he will send you Jesus, the one he chose and appointed to be his Messiah.

21.verse: He must be received in heaven, you see, until the time which God spoke about through the mouth of his holy prophets from ancient days, the time when God will restore all things.

22.verse: Moses said, “The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me, one from among your own brothers; whatever he says to you, you must pay attention to him.

23.verse: And everyone who does not listen to that prophet will be cut off from the people.”

24.verse: All the prophets who have spoken, from Samuel and his successors, spoke about these days too.

25.verse: You are the children of the prophets, the children of the covenant which God established with your ancestors when he said to Abraham, “In your seed shall all the families of the earth be blessed.”

26.verse: When God raised up his servant he sent him to you first, to bless you by turning each of you away from your wicked deeds.’

1.verse: Resurrection Plus the Name of Jesus Equals Trouble - As they were speaking to the people, along came the priests, the chief of the Temple police, and the Sadducees.

2.verse: They were thoroughly annoyed that they were teaching the people and proclaiming that ‘the resurrection of the dead’ had begun to happen in Jesus.

3.verse: They seized them and put them under guard until the next day, since it was already evening.

4.verse: But a large number of the people who had heard the message believed it, and the number of men grew to five thousand.

5.verse: On the next day their rulers, the elders and the scribes gathered in Jerusalem,

6.verse: along with Annas the high priest, Caiaphas, John, Alexander and all the members of the high-priestly family.

7.verse: They stood them in the midst. ‘How did you do this?’ they asked them. ‘What power did you use? What name did you invoke?’

8.verse: Peter was filled with the holy spirit. ‘Rulers of the people and elders,’ he said,

9.verse: ‘if the question we’re being asked today is about a good deed done for a sick man, and whose power it was that rescued him,

10.verse: let it be known to all of you, and to all the people of Israel, that this man stands before you fit and well because of the name of the Messiah, Jesus of Nazareth, whom you crucified, but whom God raised from the dead.

11.verse: He is the stone which you builders rejected, but which has become the head cornerstone.

12.verse: Rescue won’t come from anybody else! There is no other name given under heaven and among humans by which we must be rescued.’

13.verse: The Clash of Loyalties - When they saw how boldly Peter and John were speaking, and realized that they were untrained, ordinary men, they were astonished, and they recognized them as people who had been with Jesus.

14.verse: And when they saw the man who had been healed standing with them, they had nothing to say in reply.

15.verse: They ordered them to be put out of the assembly while they conferred among themselves.

16.verse: ‘What can we do to these men?’ they said. ‘This is a spectacular sign that has happened through them. All Jerusalem knows it, and we can’t deny it!

17.verse: But we certainly don’t want it to spread any further among the people. So let’s threaten them with awful consequences if they speak any more in this name to anybody.’

18.verse: So they called them in and gave them orders not to speak at all, or to teach, in the name of Jesus.

19.verse: But Peter and John gave them this reply. ‘You judge’, they said, ‘whether it’s right before God to listen to you rather than to God!

20.verse: As far as we’re concerned, we can’t stop speaking about what we have seen and heard.’

21.verse: Then they threatened them some more, and let them go. They couldn’t find any way to punish them because of the people, since everyone was glorifying God for what had happened.

22.verse: After all, the man to whom this sign of healing had happened was over forty years old.

23.verse: Look upon Their Threats - When they had been released, they went back to their own people, and told them everything that the chief priests and the elders had said.

24.verse: When they heard it, they all together lifted up their voices to God. ‘Sovereign Master,’ they said, ‘you made heaven and earth, and the sea, and everything in them.

25.verse: And you said through the holy spirit, by the mouth of our ancestor David, your servant, Why did the nations fly into a rage, and why did the peoples think empty thoughts?

26.verse: The kings of the earth arose and the rulers gathered themselves together against the Lord and against his anointed Messiah.

27.verse: ‘It’s true: Herod and Pontius Pilate, together with the nations and the peoples of Israel, gathered themselves together in this very city against your holy child Jesus, the one you anointed,

28.verse: to do whatever your hand and your plan had foreordained to take place.

29.verse: So now, Master, look on their threats; and grant that we, your servants, may speak your word with all boldness,

30.verse: while you stretch out your hand for healing, so that signs and wonders may come about through the name of your holy child Jesus.’

31.verse: When they had prayed, the place where they were gathered was shaken. They were all filled with the holy spirit, and they boldly spoke the word of God.

32.verse: Signs of the New Covenant - The company of those who believed had one heart and soul. Nobody said that they owned their property; instead, they had everything in common.

33.verse: The apostles gave their testimony to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus with great power, and great grace was upon all of them.

34.verse: For there was no needy person among them, since any who possessed lands or houses sold them, brought the money from the sale,

35.verse: and placed it at the feet of the apostles, who then gave to each according to their need.

36.verse: Joseph, a Levite from Cyprus, to whom the apostles gave the surname ‘Barnabas’ (which means ‘son of encouragement’),

37.verse: sold some land which belonged to him, brought the money, and laid it at the apostles’ feet.

1.verse: Disaster - There was, however, a man named Ananias, married to a woman called Sapphira. He sold some property,

2.verse: and, with his wife’s knowledge, kept back part of the price. He brought the rest and laid it at the apostles’ feet.

3.verse: ‘Ananias!’ said Peter. ‘Why did the satan fill your heart, to make you tell a lie to the holy spirit and to keep back part of the price of the land?

4.verse: While it was still yours, it belonged to you, didn’t it? And, when you sold it, it was still in your power! Why did you get such an idea in your heart? It isn’t humans that you’ve lied to: it’s God!’

5.verse: When Ananias heard these words, he fell down and died. Everyone who heard about it was scared out of their wits.

6.verse: The young men got up, took him away, wrapped up his body and buried him.

7.verse: After an interval of about three hours, his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.

8.verse: Peter spoke to her. ‘Tell me,’ he said, ‘did you sell the land for this much?’ ‘Yes,’ she replied, ‘that was the price.’

9.verse: ‘So why’, Peter answered, ‘did you agree together to put the holy spirit to the test? Look: the feet of those who have buried your husband are at the door – and they will carry you out too!’

10.verse: At once she fell down at his feet and died. The young men were just coming in, and they found her dead, so they took her out and buried her beside her husband.

11.verse: Great fear came upon the whole gathering, and on all who heard about these things.

12.verse: Healed by Peter’s Shadow - Many signs and wonders were performed by the apostles among the people. They were all together in Solomon’s Porch,

13.verse: while none of the others dared to join them, though the people spoke highly of them.

14.verse: But more people, a crowd both of men and women, believed in the Lord, and were added to their number.

15.verse: They used to bring the sick into the streets, and place them on beds and mats so that at least Peter’s shadow might fall on them as he went by.

16.verse: Crowds gathered from the towns around Jerusalem, bringing people who were sick, or infested with unclean spirits. All of them were cured.

17.verse: The Words of This Life - Then the high priest got up, and all who were with him, namely the group called the ‘Sadducees’. They were filled with righteous indignation,

18.verse: and seized the apostles and put them in the public jail.

19.verse: But an angel of the Lord came in the night, opened the prison doors, and brought them out.

20.verse: ‘Go and take your stand in the Temple’, he said, ‘and speak all the words of this Life to the people.’

21.verse: When they heard this, they went in at early morning and began to teach. When the high priest arrived with his entourage, they called the official Assembly and all the elders of the children of Israel, and they sent to the prison to have the apostles brought in.

22.verse: But when the attendants went, they didn’t find them in the prison. So they came and reported back.

23.verse: ‘We found the jail shut up with maximum security’, they said, ‘and the guards were standing in front of the doors. But when we opened up we found nobody inside.’

24.verse: When they heard these words, the commander of the Temple police and the chief priests were at a loss about them, with no idea what had happened.

25.verse: But then someone came with a message for them. ‘Look!’ he said. ‘The men you put in prison are standing in the Temple and teaching the people!’

26.verse: Then the commander went with his attendants and brought them. They didn’t use force, though, because they were afraid that the people might stone them.

27.verse: Human Inventions and Divine Instructions - So they brought them and stood them in the Assembly. The high priest questioned them.

28.verse: ‘We gave you strict orders, didn’t we?’ he demanded. ‘We told you not to teach in this Name, and look what you’re doing! You have filled Jerusalem with your teaching, and you’re trying to bring this man’s blood on us!’

29.verse: ‘We must obey God, not human beings!’ responded Peter and the apostles.

30.verse: ‘The God of our ancestors raised Jesus, after you had laid violent hands on him and hanged him on a tree.

31.verse: God exalted him to his right hand as Leader and Saviour, to give repentance to Israel and forgiveness of sins.

32.verse: We are witnesses of these things, and so is the holy spirit, which God gave to those who obey him.’

33.verse: When they heard this, they were infuriated, and wanted to kill them.

34.verse: But then a Pharisee by the name of Gamaliel stood up in the Assembly. He was a law-teacher, highly respected by all the people. He ordered the men to be put outside for a short while.

35.verse: ‘Men of Israel,’ he said to the gathering, ‘be careful what you do to these men.

36.verse: Before these times Theudas rose up, claiming to be someone special, and about four hundred men went off to join him. But he was killed, and all the people who had trusted him were dispersed. The movement came to nothing.

37.verse: After that, Judas the Galilean arose, in the days of the Census, and drew a crowd after himself. But he was killed, and all those who trusted him were scattered.

38.verse: So my advice to you now is this. Leave off from these men; let them be. You see, if this plan or this work is of merely human origin, it will come to ruin.

39.verse: But if it’s from God – well, you won’t be able to stop them. You might even be found to be fighting against God!’ They were persuaded by him,

40.verse: and they called the apostles back in. They beat them and told them not to speak in the name of Jesus. Then they let them go.

41.verse: They, however, went out from the presence of the Assembly celebrating, because they had been reckoned worthy to suffer disgrace for the Name.

42.verse: And all day, in the Temple and from house to house, they did not stop teaching and proclaiming Jesus as the Messiah.

1.verse: Problems of Family Living - Around that time, as the number of disciples increased, the ‘Hellenists’ raised a dispute with the ‘Hebrews’ because their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution of food.

2.verse: So the Twelve called the whole crowd of disciples together. ‘Listen,’ they said. ‘It wouldn’t be right for us to leave the word of God to wait on tables.

3.verse: So, brothers and sisters, choose seven men from among yourselves who are well spoken of and filled with the spirit and wisdom. We will put them in charge of what needs to be done in this matter.

4.verse: We will continue to pay attention to prayer and to the ministry of the word.’

5.verse: The whole gathering was pleased with what they said. They chose Stephen, a man full of faith and the holy spirit, and Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas and Nicolaus (a proselyte from Antioch).

6.verse: They presented them before the apostles, who prayed and laid their hands on them.

7.verse: The word of God increased, and the number of disciples in Jerusalem grew by leaps and bounds. This included a large crowd of priests who became obedient to the faith.

8.verse: Stephen Becomes a Target - Stephen was filled with grace and power, and performed great signs and wonders among the people.

9.verse: But some from the ‘Freemen’s Synagogue’, as it was named, and from Cyrene, Alexandria, Cilicia and Asia, stood up and disputed with Stephen.

10.verse: They could not, however, resist the wisdom and the spirit with which he spoke.

11.verse: Then they put up men to say, ‘We heard this man speaking blasphemous words against Moses and against God!’

12.verse: They aroused the people, the elders and the scribes. They set upon him, seized him, and took him in front of the Assembly.

13.verse: They set up false witnesses to say, ‘This man never stops speaking words against this holy place and the law!

14.verse: We heard him say that this Jesus the Nazorean will destroy this place, and change the customs which Moses handed down to us!’

15.verse: Everyone who was sitting in the Assembly looked hard at Stephen. They all saw that his face was like the face of an angel.

1.verse: Stephen Tells the Story - The high priest addressed Stephen. ‘Are these things true?’ he said.

2.verse: ‘My brothers and fathers,’ replied Stephen, ‘please give me a hearing. ‘The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, before he moved to live in Haran.

3.verse: “Leave your land and your family,” he said to him, “and go to the land which I will show you.”

4.verse: So he left the land of the Chaldeans and went to live in Haran. Then, from there, after his father’s death, God moved him on to this land in which you now live.

5.verse: God didn’t give him an inheritance here, not even a place to stand up in. Instead, he promised (when Abraham still had no child) that he would give it as a possession to his seed after him.

6.verse: This is what God said to him: that his seed would be strangers in a foreign land, that they would serve there as slaves, and that they would be afflicted for four hundred years.

7.verse: But God said that he would judge the nation that had enslaved them, and that they would then come out and worship him “on this mountain”.

8.verse: And he gave them the covenant of circumcision. So Abraham became the father of Isaac, and he circumcised him on the eighth day. Isaac became the father of Jacob, and Jacob the father of the twelve patriarchs.

9.verse: ‘Now the patriarchs became angry with Joseph, and were jealous of him. They sold him into Egypt. But God was with him,

10.verse: and rescued him from all his troubles and gave him grace and wisdom before Pharaoh, king of Egypt, making him ruler over Egypt and over all his household.

11.verse: But then there was a famine over the whole of Egypt and Canaan, which resulted in great hardship. Our ancestors couldn’t find food to eat.

12.verse: Jacob, however, heard that there was grain in Egypt, and sent our ancestors there on an initial visit.

13.verse: On their second trip, Joseph made himself known to his brothers, and revealed to Pharaoh what family he was from.

14.verse: So Joseph sent and summoned Jacob his father and all the family, seventy-five people in all.

15.verse: Jacob came to Egypt, and he and our ancestors died there.

16.verse: They were brought back to Shechem, and buried in the tomb which Abraham had bought with silver, at a named price, from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.’

17.verse: Stephen and Moses - ‘God had sworn an oath to Abraham,’ Stephen continued. ‘When the time drew near for this promise to be fulfilled, the people had increased and multiplied in Egypt,

18.verse: until another king arose over Egypt, one who had not known Joseph.

19.verse: He got the better of our people, and ill-treated our ancestors, forcing them to abandon their newborn children so that they would die.

20.verse: ‘It was at that time that Moses was born, and he was a noble-looking child. He was nursed for three months in his father’s house.

21.verse: But, when they abandoned him, Pharaoh’s daughter claimed him and brought him up as her own son.

22.verse: So Moses was educated in the full teaching of Egyptian wisdom, and he was powerful in what he said and did.

23.verse: ‘When he had grown to about forty years old, it came into his heart to see how his family, the children of Israel, were doing.

24.verse: He saw someone being wronged, and came to the man’s defence; he took revenge on behalf of the man who was being oppressed, by striking down the Egyptian.

25.verse: He thought his kinsfolk would grasp the fact that God was sending him to their rescue, but they didn’t.

26.verse: ‘The next day he showed up as two Hebrews were fighting, and he tried to bring them back together again. “Now then, you two,” he said, “you are brothers! Why are you wronging each other?”

27.verse: But the man who was wronging the other wasn’t having it. “Who d’you think you are?” he retorted, pushing him away. “Who made you a ruler or judge over us?

28.verse: Do you want to kill me in the same way you killed the Egyptian yesterday?”

29.verse: At that word, Moses ran away, and lived as a guest in the land of Midian, where he had two sons.

30.verse: ‘After another forty years, an angel appeared to him in the desert at Mount Sinai, in the flame of a burning bush.

31.verse: When Moses saw it, he was amazed at the vision. But, as he came closer to see, there came the voice of the Lord:

32.verse: “I am the God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob.” Moses was very frightened, and didn’t dare to look.

33.verse: But the Lord said to him, “Take your sandals off your feet, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.

34.verse: I have looked long and hard at the trouble my people are having in Egypt. I have heard their groaning, and I have come down to rescue them. So, come on now: I’m going to send you to Egypt.” ’

35.verse: Handmade Shrines - ‘So’, Stephen continued, ‘this same Moses – the one they rejected, saying “Who made you a ruler or judge?” – this is the man God sent as ruler and redeemer, by the hand of the angel who had appeared to him in the bush.

36.verse: He did signs and wonders in the land of Egypt, and led them out, through the Red Sea and for forty years in the wilderness.

37.verse: This is the Moses who said to the children of Israel, “God will raise up a prophet like me from among your brothers.”

38.verse: And this is the one who was in the Assembly in the desert with the angel who had spoken to him on Mount Sinai, and with our ancestors; and he received living words to give to us.

39.verse: ‘This is the one whom our ancestors had not wanted to obey, but instead rejected him and turned back in their hearts to Egypt,

40.verse: by saying to Aaron, “Make us gods who will go before us; for this Moses, who brought us out of the land of Egypt – we don’t know what has become of him!”

41.verse: They made a calf in those days, and offered sacrifice to an idol. They celebrated things their own hands had made.

42.verse: ‘Then God turned and handed them over to worship the host of heaven, as it stands written in the book of the prophets: “Did you bring sacrifices and offerings to me in those forty years in the wilderness, O house of Israel?

43.verse: You took up the tent of Moloch, and the star of your god Rhephan, the carved images you made to worship! I will remove you beyond Babylon!”

44.verse: ‘Our ancestors had the “tent of meeting” in the desert. God had commanded Moses to make it according to the pattern which he had seen.

45.verse: Our ancestors in their turn brought it in when, with Joshua, they dispossessed the nations whom God drove out before our ancestors, and it was there until the time of David.

46.verse: David found favour with God, and requested permission to establish a Tabernacle for the house of Jacob.

47.verse: But it was Solomon who built him a house.

48.verse: ‘The Most High, however, does not live in shrines made by human hands. The prophet put it like this:

49.verse: Heaven is my throne, and earth my footstool! What sort of house will you build me, says the Lord, or what place will you give me to rest in?

50.verse: My own hand made all these, did it not?

51.verse: ‘You stiff-necked people! Your hearts and ears are uncircumcised! You always resist the holy spirit, just as your ancestors did before you!

52.verse: Which of the prophets did your ancestors not persecute? And you killed those who announced in advance the coming of the Righteous One – and now you have betrayed him and murdered him.

53.verse: You received the law at the command of angels, but you didn’t keep it!’

54.verse: The Stoning of Stephen - What Stephen said was a blow right to the heart. When they heard it, they gnashed their teeth against him.

55.verse: He, however, was filled with the holy spirit, and looked steadily up into heaven. There he saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing at God’s right hand.

56.verse: ‘Look!’ he said. ‘I can see heaven opened, and the son of man standing at God’s right hand!’

57.verse: But they yelled at him at the tops of their voices, blocked their ears and made a concerted dash at him.

58.verse: They bundled him out of the city and stoned him. The witnesses laid down their cloaks at the feet of a young man named Saul.

59.verse: So they stoned Stephen. ‘Lord Jesus,’ he cried out, ‘receive my spirit.’

60.verse: Then he knelt down, and shouted at the top of his voice, ‘Lord, don’t let this sin stand against them.’ Once he had said this, he fell asleep.

1.verse: Now Saul was giving his consent to Stephen’s death. That very day a great persecution was started against the church in Jerusalem. Everyone except the apostles was scattered through the lands of Judaea and Samaria.

2.verse: Devout men buried Stephen, and made a great lamentation over him.

3.verse: But Saul was doing great damage to the church by going from one house to another, dragging off men and women and throwing them into prison.

4.verse: Samaria, the Spirit and Simon Magus - Those who were scattered went all over the place announcing the word.

5.verse: Philip went off to a town in Samaria and announced the Messiah to them.

6.verse: The crowds, acting as one, clung to what Philip was saying, as they heard him and saw the signs he performed.

7.verse: For unclean spirits came out of many of them, and several who were paralysed or lame were cured.

8.verse: So there was great joy in that town.

9.verse: But there was a man named Simon, who had lived in the town for some while and who practised magic. He used to astonish the Samaritan people, giving out that he was some great personage.

10.verse: Everyone, small and great alike, paid attention to him, and said, ‘This man is the one called “God’s Great Power”!’

11.verse: They had been under his spell for some time, since they were amazed at the magic he could perform.

12.verse: But when they believed Philip as he was announcing to them the message about God’s kingdom and the Name of Jesus the Messiah, they were baptized, men and women alike.

13.verse: Simon too believed and was baptized, paying close attention to Philip. When he saw signs, and great and powerful deeds, it was his turn to be astonished.

14.verse: When the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received God’s word, they sent Peter and John to them.

15.verse: When they arrived, they prayed for them, asking that they would receive the holy spirit,

16.verse: since up to that point the spirit had come upon none of them; they had simply been baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus.

17.verse: Then they laid their hands on them, and they received the holy spirit.

18.verse: When Simon saw that the spirit was given through the laying on of the apostles’ hands, he offered them money.

19.verse: ‘Give me this power too,’ he said, ‘so that anyone I lay my hands on will receive the holy spirit.’

20.verse: ‘You and your silver belong in hell!’ retorted Peter. ‘Did you really think that God’s gift could be bought with money?

21.verse: You have no part or share in this word! Your heart is not straight before God.

22.verse: So repent from this wickedness, and pray to the Lord. Perhaps he will forgive the scheme you had in your heart.

23.verse: I can see that you are still stuck in the bitter poison and chains of unrighteousness.’

24.verse: ‘Pray to the Lord for me’, said Simon in reply, ‘that none of what you’ve said will happen to me.’

25.verse: After Peter and John had finished bearing witness and speaking the word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem, announcing the good news to many Samaritan villages.

26.verse: Philip and the Ethiopian - An angel of the Lord spoke to Philip. ‘Get up and go south,’ he said. ‘Go to the desert road that runs down from Jerusalem to Gaza.’

27.verse: So he got up and went. Lo and behold, there was an Ethiopian eunuch, a court official of the Candace (the queen of Ethiopia), who was in charge of her whole treasury. He had come to Jerusalem to worship,

28.verse: and was on his way back home. He was sitting in his chariot and reading the prophet Isaiah.

29.verse: ‘Go up and join his chariot,’ said the spirit to Philip.

30.verse: So Philip ran up, and heard him reading the prophet Isaiah. ‘Do you understand what you’re reading?’ he asked.

31.verse: ‘How can I’, he replied, ‘unless someone gives me some help?’ So he invited Philip to get up and sit beside him.

32.verse: The biblical passage he was reading was this one: He was led like a sheep to the slaughter and as a lamb is silent before its shearers, so he does not open his mouth.

33.verse: In his humiliation, judgment was taken away from him. Who can explain his generation? For his life was taken away from the earth.

34.verse: ‘Tell me,’ said the eunuch to Philip, ‘who is the prophet talking about? Himself or someone else?’

35.verse: Then Philip took a deep breath and, starting from this biblical passage, told him the good news about Jesus.

36.verse: As they were going along the road, they came to some water. ‘Look!’ said the eunuch. ‘Here is some water! What’s to stop me being baptized?’

37.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

38.verse: So he gave orders for the chariot to stop, and both of them went down into the water, Philip and the eunuch together, and he baptized him.

39.verse: When they came up out of the water, the spirit of the Lord snatched Philip away, and the eunuch didn’t see him any more, but went on his way rejoicing.

40.verse: Philip, however, turned up at Azotus. He went through all the towns, announcing the good news, until he came to Caesarea.

1.verse: The Conversion of Saul - Meanwhile, Saul was still breathing out threats and murder on the Lord’s disciples. He went to the high priest

2.verse: and requested from him official letters to the synagogues in Damascus, so that he could find people who belonged to the Way, men and women alike, tie them up and bring them back to Jerusalem.

3.verse: While he was on the journey, and was getting near to Damascus, suddenly a light from heaven shone around him.

4.verse: He fell on the ground and heard a voice speaking to him. ‘Saul, Saul!’ said the voice. ‘Why are you persecuting me?’

5.verse: ‘Who are you, Lord?’ he asked. ‘I am Jesus,’ he said, ‘and you are persecuting me.

6.verse: But get up and go into the city, and it will be told you what you have to do.’

7.verse: The men who were travelling with Saul stood speechless. They heard the voice but couldn’t see anybody.

8.verse: Saul got up from the ground, but when he opened his eyes he couldn’t see anything. So they led him by the hand and brought him to Damascus.

9.verse: He went for three days, being unable to see, and he neither ate nor drank.

10.verse: Ananias and Saul - In Damascus there was a disciple named Ananias. The Lord spoke to him in a vision. ‘Ananias!’ he said. ‘Here I am, Lord,’ he replied.

11.verse: ‘Get up’, said the Lord to him, ‘and go to the street called Straight. Enquire at the house of Judas for a man from Tarsus named Saul. Look – he’s praying!

12.verse: And he has seen, in a vision, a man named Ananias coming and laying his hands on him so that he can see again.’

13.verse: ‘Well, Lord,’ replied Ananias, ‘I’ve heard about this man from several people . . . all about how he’s done wicked things to your holy people in Jerusalem . . .

14.verse: and now he’s come here with authority from the chief priests to tie up everybody who calls on your Name!’

15.verse: ‘Just go,’ replied the Lord. ‘He is a chosen vessel for me, to carry my Name before nations and kings – and the children of Israel, too.

16.verse: I am going to show him how many things he is going to have to suffer for the sake of my Name.’

17.verse: So Ananias set off, went into the house, and laid his hands on him. ‘Brother Saul,’ he said, ‘the Lord has sent me – yes, Jesus, who appeared to you on the road as you were coming here – so that you may be able to see again, and receive the holy spirit.’

18.verse: At once something like scales fell off his eyes, and he was able to see. He got up and was baptized.

19.verse: He had something to eat, and regained his strength. ‘He is God’s Son’ - Saul stayed with the disciples in Damascus for a few days.

20.verse: At once he proclaimed Jesus in the synagogues, saying, ‘This really is the son of God!’

21.verse: Everyone was astonished, and said, ‘Isn’t this the man who caused havoc to those in Jerusalem who call on this Name? And here he is, coming to tie them up and take them off to the high priests!’

22.verse: But Saul grew all the stronger, and threw the Jews in Damascus into confusion by demonstrating that Jesus is indeed the Messiah.

23.verse: After some days, the Jews made a plot to kill him,

24.verse: but Saul got wind of their plan. They were watching the city gates day and night so that they could do away with him.

25.verse: But the disciples took him by night and let him down through the wall, lowering him in a basket.

26.verse: When he got back to Jerusalem he tried to join the disciples, but they were all afraid of him, not believing that he really was a disciple.

27.verse: But Barnabas took him, brought him to the apostles, and explained to them how he had seen the Lord on the road, and that he had spoken to him, and how in Damascus he had spoken boldly in the name of Jesus.

28.verse: He was with them in Jerusalem, coming and going and speaking boldly in the name of the Lord.

29.verse: He spoke, as well, to the Hellenists, who tried to kill him.

30.verse: But the family heard of it and took him down to Caesarea. There they sent him off to Tarsus.

31.verse: So the church in all Judaea, Galilee and Samaria found itself at peace. It was built up and gained in numbers, living in the fear of the Lord and the comfort of the holy spirit.

32.verse: Back to Peter - As Peter was going through various places among all the believers, he went down to God’s people who lived in Lydda.

33.verse: There he found a paralysed man named Aeneas who had been confined to bed for eight years.

34.verse: ‘Aeneas,’ Peter said to him, ‘Jesus the Messiah heals you! Stand up and fold up your bed!’ And at once he stood up.

35.verse: Everyone who lived at Lydda and Sharon saw it, and they turned to the Lord.

36.verse: In Joppa there was a disciple named Tabitha, whose name translates as ‘Dorcas’. She was full of good works and generous deeds.

37.verse: Around that time she fell ill and died. They washed her and laid her in an upper room.

38.verse: Lydda is near Joppa, and the disciples, hearing that Peter was there, sent two men to him with the urgent request that he shouldn’t delay, but come to them at once.

39.verse: So Peter got up and went with them. When he arrived, they took him to the upper room, where all the widows were weeping. They showed him the tunics and the other clothes that Dorcas had made while she was with them.

40.verse: Peter requested them all to leave. Then he knelt down and prayed, and turned to the body. ‘Tabitha,’ he said, ‘get up!’ She opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter she sat up.

41.verse: He gave her his hand and lifted her up. Then he called God’s people, including the widows, and presented her alive.

42.verse: This became known throughout the whole of Joppa, and many believed in the Lord.

43.verse: Peter stayed on in Joppa for some days, at the house of Simon the tanner.

1.verse: Peter’s Vision - In Caesarea there was a man named Cornelius, a centurion with the cohort called ‘the Italian’.

2.verse: He was devout, and he and all his household revered God. He gave alms generously to the people, and constantly prayed to God.

3.verse: He had a vision. Around three o’clock in the afternoon he saw, quite clearly, one of God’s angels coming to him. ‘Cornelius!’ said the angel.

4.verse: He looked hard at him, terrified. ‘What is it, Sir?’ he said. ‘Your prayers and your alms have come to God’s notice,’ said the angel.

5.verse: ‘What you must do is this. Send men to Joppa, and ask for someone called Simon, surnamed Peter.

6.verse: He is staying with a man called Simon, a tanner, whose house is beside the sea.’

7.verse: When the angel who had spoken with him went away, he called two of his household and a devout soldier from among his retinue.

8.verse: He explained everything to them, and sent them off to Joppa.

9.verse: The next day, as they were on their journey and getting near the town, Peter went up onto the roof of the house to pray. It was around midday;

10.verse: he was hungry, and asked for something to eat. While they were preparing it, he fell into a trance.

11.verse: He saw heaven opened, and a vessel like a great sail coming down towards the earth, suspended by its four corners.

12.verse: In the sail there was every kind of four-footed creature, reptiles of the earth and birds of the air.

13.verse: Then he heard a voice: ‘Get up, Peter!’ said the voice. ‘Kill and eat!’

14.verse: ‘Certainly not, Master!’ said Peter. ‘I’ve never eaten anything common or unclean!’

15.verse: ‘What God has made clean,’ said the voice, coming now for a second time, ‘you must not regard as common.’

16.verse: This all happened three times, and then suddenly the sail was whisked back up to heaven.

17.verse: Peter Goes to Cornelius - When Peter came to himself, he was puzzled as to what the vision he had seen was all about. Then, suddenly, the men sent by Cornelius appeared, standing by the gate. They had been asking for Simon’s house,

18.verse: enquiring if someone by the name of Simon called Peter was staying there.

19.verse: Peter was still pondering the vision, when the spirit spoke to him. ‘Look,’ said the spirit. ‘There are three men searching for you.

20.verse: It’s all right; get up, go down and go with them. Don’t be prejudiced; I have sent them.’

21.verse: So Peter went down to the men. ‘Here I am,’ he said. ‘I’m the one you’re looking for. Why have you come?’

22.verse: ‘There is a man called Cornelius,’ they replied. ‘He is a centurion, and he’s a righteous and God-fearing man. The whole people of the Jews will testify to him. A holy angel told him in a vision to send for you to come to his house, so that he can hear any words you may have to say.’

23.verse: So he invited them in and put them up for the night. In the morning he got up and went with them. Some of the believers from Joppa went with him.

24.verse: They reached Caesarea the following day. Cornelius had summoned his relatives and close friends and was waiting for him.

25.verse: When Peter came in, Cornelius went to meet him. He fell down at his feet and worshipped him.

26.verse: ‘Get up!’ said Peter, lifting him up. ‘I’m just a man, too.’

27.verse: So they talked together, and Peter came in and found lots of people assembled.

28.verse: ‘You must know’, he said to them, ‘that it is forbidden for a Jewish man to mix with or visit a Gentile. But God showed me that I should call nobody “common” or “unclean”.

29.verse: So I came when I was asked, and raised no objections. Do tell me, then, the reason why you sent for me.’

30.verse: Cornelius gave him the answer. ‘Four days ago’, he said, ‘I was praying in my house at around this time, about three o’clock, and suddenly a man stood beside me in shining clothes.

31.verse: “Cornelius,” he said, “your prayer has been heard, and your almsgiving has been remembered by God.

32.verse: So send someone to Joppa and call Simon, who is named Peter; he is staying in the house of Simon the tanner, beside the sea.”

33.verse: So I sent for you at once, and you have been kind enough to come. So now we are all here, in God’s presence, to listen to everything which the Lord has told you to say.’

34.verse: Telling the Gentiles about Jesus - Peter took a deep breath and began. ‘It’s become clear to me’, he said, ‘that God really does show no favouritism.

35.verse: No: in every race, people who fear him and do what is right are acceptable to him.

36.verse: He sent his word to the children of Israel, announcing peace through Jesus Christ – he is Lord of all!

37.verse: You know all about this, and how the word spread through all Judaea, beginning from Galilee after the baptism which John proclaimed.

38.verse: ‘God anointed this man, Jesus of Nazareth, with the holy spirit and with power. He went about doing good and healing all who were overpowered by the devil, since God was with him.

39.verse: We are witnesses of everything he did in the land of Judaea and in Jerusalem. They killed him by hanging him on a tree;

40.verse: but God raised him on the third day, and allowed him to be seen,

41.verse: not indeed by all the people, but by those of us whom God had appointed beforehand. We ate and drank with him after he had been raised from the dead.

42.verse: And he commanded us to announce to the people, and to bear testimony, that he is the one appointed by God to be judge of the living and the dead.

43.verse: All the prophets give their witness: he is the one! Everyone who believes in him receives forgiveness of sins through his Name.’

44.verse: While Peter was still speaking these words, the holy spirit fell on everyone who was listening to the word.

45.verse: The circumcised believers who had accompanied Peter were astonished, because the gift of the holy spirit had been poured out on the Gentiles too.

46.verse: They heard them speaking with tongues and praising God. Then Peter spoke up.

47.verse: ‘Nobody can deny these people water to be baptized, can they?’ he said. ‘They have received the holy spirit, just like we did!’

48.verse: So he ordered them to be baptized in the name of Jesus the Messiah. Then they asked him to stay for a few days.

1.verse: Controversy and Vindication - The apostles, and the brothers and sisters with them in Judaea, heard that the Gentiles had received the word of God.

2.verse: So when Peter went up to Jerusalem, those who wanted to emphasize circumcision took issue with him.

3.verse: ‘Why did you do it?’ they asked. ‘Why did you go in to visit uncircumcised men and eat with them?’

4.verse: So Peter began to explain it all, step by step.

5.verse: ‘I was in the town of Joppa’, he said, ‘and I was praying. I was in a trance, and I saw a vision: something like a great sail suspended by its four corners was let down from heaven, and came towards me.

6.verse: I stared at it, then I began to look in, and I saw four-footed land animals, wild beasts, reptiles and birds of the air.

7.verse: I heard a voice, saying to me, “Get up, Peter! Kill and eat!”

8.verse: “Certainly not, Lord,” I replied. “Nothing common or unclean has ever entered my mouth!”

9.verse: Then the voice came from heaven a second time: “What God made clean, you must not regard as common.”

10.verse: All this happened three times, and then the whole lot was drawn back up into heaven.

11.verse: ‘Just then, suddenly, three men appeared at the house where I was, sent to me from Caesarea.

12.verse: The spirit told me to go with them, without raising scrupulous objections. These six brothers also came with me, and we went into the man’s house.

13.verse: He told us that he had seen an angel standing in his house and saying, “Send to Joppa and fetch Simon called Peter,

14.verse: who will speak to you words by which you and all your house will be saved.”

15.verse: As I began to speak, the holy spirit fell on them, just as the spirit did on us at the beginning.

16.verse: And I remembered the word which the Lord had spoken: “John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the holy spirit.”

17.verse: ‘So, then,’ Peter concluded, ‘if God gave them the same gift as he gave to us when we believed in the Lord Jesus the Messiah, who was I to stand in the way of God?’

18.verse: When they heard this, they had nothing more to say. They praised God. ‘Well, then,’ they declared, ‘God has given the Gentiles, too, the repentance that leads to life!’

19.verse: Taking Root – and a Name! – in Antioch - The people who had been scattered because of the persecution that came about over Stephen went as far afield as Phoenicia, Cyprus and Antioch, speaking the word only to Jewish people.

20.verse: But some from among them, who were from Cyprus and Cyrene in the first place, arrived in Antioch and spoke to the Hellenists as well, announcing the good news of the Lord Jesus.

21.verse: The Lord’s hand was with them, and a large number of people believed and turned to the Lord.

22.verse: News of all this reached the ears of the church in Jerusalem, and they sent Barnabas to Antioch.

23.verse: When he arrived and saw the grace of God he was glad, and he urged them all to stay firmly loyal to the Lord from the bottom of their hearts.

24.verse: He was a good man, full of the holy spirit and faith. And a substantial crowd was added to the Lord.

25.verse: Then Barnabas went to Tarsus to look for Saul

26.verse: and, when he had found him, he brought him to Antioch. They were there a whole year, and were received hospitably in the church, and taught a substantial crowd. And it was in Antioch that the disciples were first called ‘Christians’.

27.verse: Around that time, prophets came from Jerusalem to Antioch.

28.verse: One of them, Agabus by name, stood up and gave an indication through the spirit that there would be a great famine over the whole world. (This took place in the reign of Claudius.)

29.verse: Each of the disciples determined, according to their ability, to send what they could to help the brothers and sisters living in Judaea.

30.verse: They carried out this plan, sending their gift to the elders by the hand of Barnabas and Saul.

1.verse: Herod Kills James - Around that time, King Herod began to use violence towards some people in the church.

2.verse: He killed James the brother of John with the sword.

3.verse: When he saw that it pleased the Judaeans, he proceeded to arrest Peter, too. (This was around the time of the Festival of Unleavened Bread.)

4.verse: So, when he had seized him, he put him in prison, and gave four squads of soldiers the job of guarding him, with the intention of bringing him out to the people after Passover.

5.verse: So Peter was kept in prison. But the church prayed earnestly to God on his behalf.

6.verse: Peter’s Rescue and Rhoda’s Mistake - On the night when Herod was intending to bring Peter out, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains. There were guards on the doors, watching the prison.

7.verse: Suddenly an angel of the Lord stood there, and a light shone in the cell. The angel hit Peter on the side and woke him up. ‘Get up quickly!’ he said. The chains fell off his hands.

8.verse: Then the angel spoke again. ‘Get dressed and put on your sandals,’ he said. So Peter did. ‘Put on your cloak and follow me,’ said the angel.

9.verse: So he went out, following the angel. He didn’t think all this business with the angel was really happening. He thought he was seeing a vision.

10.verse: They went through the first set of guards; then the second; and then they came to the iron gate that led into the city. It opened all by itself. They went out and walked along a street. Suddenly the angel left him.

11.verse: Then Peter came to his senses. ‘Now I know it’s true!’ he said. ‘The Lord sent his angel and snatched me out of Herod’s hands. He rescued me from all the things the Judaeans were intending to do.’

12.verse: Once he had realized this, he went to the house of Mary, John Mark’s mother. Lots of people were gathered there, praying.

13.verse: Peter knocked at the door in the outer gate, and a maid called Rhoda came to answer it.

14.verse: When she heard Peter’s voice, she was so excited she didn’t open the gate. Instead, she ran back in and told them that Peter was standing outside the gate.

15.verse: ‘You’re mad!’ they said to her. But she insisted that it really was true. ‘It must be his angel!’ they said.

16.verse: Meanwhile Peter carried on knocking. They opened the door and saw him, and were astonished.

17.verse: He made a sign with his hand for them to be quiet. Then he told them how the Lord had led him out of the prison. ‘Tell this to James, and to the other brothers and sisters,’ he said. Then he left, and went somewhere else.

18.verse: When morning came, there was quite a commotion among the guards as to what had become of Peter.

19.verse: Herod looked for him but couldn’t find him. He interrogated the guards and ordered them to be put to death. Then he left Judaea and went down to Caesarea, and stayed there.

20.verse: Herod’s Vanity and Death - Now Herod was angry with the people of Tyre and Sidon. They all came together to meet him, and they persuaded Blastus, who was in charge of the king’s bedchamber, to seek a reconciliation. (They were, you see, dependent on the king’s country for their food.)

21.verse: So a day was set, and Herod dressed himself in his royal robes and took his seat on the official platform to make a public address to them.

22.verse: The people began to shout, ‘The voice of a god, not of a mortal!’

23.verse: Immediately an angel of the Lord struck him, because he didn’t give God the glory. He was eaten by worms and expired.

24.verse: But God’s word grew and multiplied.

25.verse: Barnabas and Saul had by now accomplished their ministry in Jerusalem, and they came back to Antioch, bringing John Mark with them.

1.verse: Mission and Magic - In the church at Antioch there were prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Symeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen from the court of Herod the Tetrarch, and Saul.

2.verse: As they were worshipping the Lord and fasting, the holy spirit said, ‘Set apart Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them.’

3.verse: So they fasted and prayed; and then they laid their hands on them and sent them off.

4.verse: So off they went, sent out by the holy spirit, and arrived at Seleucia. From there they set sail to Cyprus,

5.verse: and when they arrived in Salamis they announced God’s word in the Jewish synagogues. John was with them as their assistant.

6.verse: They went through the whole of the island, all the way to Paphos. There they found a magician, a Jewish false prophet named Bar-Jesus.

7.verse: He was with the governor, Sergius Paulus, who was an intelligent man. He called Barnabas and Saul and asked to hear the word of God.

8.verse: The magician Elymas (that is the translation of his name) was opposing them, and doing his best to turn the governor away from the faith.

9.verse: But Saul, also named Paul, looked intently at him, filled with the holy spirit.

10.verse: ‘You’re full of trickery and every kind of villainy!’ he said. ‘You’re a son of the devil! You’re an enemy of everything that’s right! When are you going to stop twisting the paths that God has made straight?

11.verse: Now see here: the Lord’s hand will be upon you, and you will be blind for a while; you won’t even be able to see the sun!’ At once mist and darkness fell on him, and he went about looking for someone to lead him by the hand.

12.verse: When the governor saw what had happened, he believed, since he was astonished at the teaching of the Lord.

13.verse: Address in Antioch - Paul and his companions set off from Paphos and came to Perga in Pamphylia. John, however, left them and went back to Jerusalem.

14.verse: But they came through from Perga and arrived in Antioch of Pisidia, where they went into the synagogue on the sabbath day and sat down.

15.verse: After the reading of the law and the prophets, the ruler of the synagogue sent word to them. ‘My brothers,’ he said, ‘if you have any word of exhortation for the people, let us hear it.’

16.verse: So Paul stood up and motioned with his hand for attention. ‘Fellow Israelites,’ he said, ‘and the god-fearers among you: listen.

17.verse: The God of this people Israel chose our ancestors, and he raised the people up to greatness during their stay in the land of Egypt. Then he led them out from there with his hand lifted high,

18.verse: and for about forty years he put up with them in the desert.

19.verse: He drove out seven nations from the land of Canaan, and gave them the land as their inheritance

20.verse: for about four hundred and fifty years. After that, he gave them judges, up until Samuel the prophet.

21.verse: After that, they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul the son of Kish, a man from the tribe of Benjamin. He ruled for forty years,

22.verse: and after God had removed him he raised up for them David as king. He is the one to whom God bore witness when he said, “I have found David, son of Jesse, a man after my own heart; he will accomplish all my purpose.”

23.verse: ‘From this man’s offspring, in accordance with his promise, God has produced a saviour for Israel: Jesus!

24.verse: Before he appeared, John had announced a baptism of repentance for the whole people of Israel.

25.verse: As John was finishing his course, he said, “What do you suppose I am? I am not the one. But look: someone is coming after me, and I am not worthy to untie the sandals on his feet.”

26.verse: The Messianic Challenge - ‘My brothers and sisters,’ Paul continued, ‘children of Abraham’s family, and the God-fearers among you: it is to us that the word of this salvation has been sent!

27.verse: The people who live in Jerusalem, and their rulers, didn’t recognize him, and they fulfilled the words of the prophets which are read to them every sabbath by condemning him.

28.verse: Even though they found no reason to condemn him to death, they asked Pilate to have him killed.

29.verse: When they had completed everything that had been written about him in prophecy, they took him down from the cross and put him in a tomb.

30.verse: But God raised him from the dead,

31.verse: and he was seen for several days by those who had come with him from Galilee to Jerusalem. They are now his witnesses to the people.

32.verse: ‘We are here now to bring you the good news which was promised to our ancestors,

33.verse: that God has fulfilled this promise to us, their children, by raising Jesus. This corresponds, indeed, to what is written in the second Psalm: You are my son; this day I have begotten you.

34.verse: ‘That he raised him from the dead, never more to return to corruption, conforms to what was written: I will give you the holy and faithful mercies of David.

35.verse: ‘Because, as it says in another place, You will not hand over your holy one to see corruption.

36.verse: ‘Now David served his own generation, and in the purposes of God he fell asleep and was gathered to his fathers. He did experience corruption.

37.verse: But the one God raised up did not experience corruption.

38.verse: So let it be known to you, my brothers and sisters, that forgiveness of sins is announced through him, and that everything from which you were unable to be set right by the law of Moses,

39.verse: by him every one who believes is set right.

40.verse: ‘Beware, then, lest what the prophets foretold comes true of you:

41.verse: Look out, you scoffers – be amazed, and disappear! I am doing something in your days, a work which you wouldn’t believe even if someone were to explain it to you.’

42.verse: As Paul and Barnabas were leaving, they begged them to come back the next sabbath and tell them more about these things.

43.verse: Many of the Jews and devout proselytes followed them once the synagogue was dismissed. They spoke to them some more, and urged them to remain in God’s grace.

44.verse: A Light to the Gentiles - On the next sabbath, almost the whole city came together to hear the word of the Lord.

45.verse: But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with righteous indignation, and spoke blasphemous words against what Paul was saying.

46.verse: Paul and Barnabas grew very bold. ‘God’s word had to be spoken to you first,’ they declared. ‘But since you are rejecting it, and judging yourselves unworthy of the life of God’s new age, look! We are turning to the Gentiles!

47.verse: This is what the Lord has commanded, you see: I have set you for a light to the nations, so that you can be salvation-bringers to the end of the earth.’

48.verse: When the Gentiles heard this, they were thrilled, and they praised the word of the Lord. All those who were marked out for the life of God’s new age became believers.

49.verse: And the word of the Lord spread through the whole land.

50.verse: But the Jews incited the devout aristocratic women and the leading men of the city. They stirred up persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and drove them out of their district.

51.verse: They, however, shook the dust off their feet and went on to Iconium.

52.verse: The disciples were filled with joy and with the holy spirit.

1.verse: Iconium - What happened in Iconium was much the same. They went into the Jewish synagogue and spoke, with the result that a large crowd, both of Jews and of Greeks, came to faith.

2.verse: But the unbelieving Jews stirred up and poisoned the minds of the Gentiles against the brothers.

3.verse: They stayed there a long time, speaking boldly on behalf of the Lord, who bore them witness to the word of his grace by giving signs and wonders which were done at their hands.

4.verse: But the inhabitants of the city were divided. Some were with the Jews, and some with the apostles.

5.verse: But then the Gentiles and Jews, with their rulers, made an attempt to ill-treat them and stone them.

6.verse: They got wind of it, however, and fled to Lystra and Derbe, cities of Lycaonia, and to the surrounding countryside.

7.verse: There they went on announcing the good news.

8.verse: Confusion in Lystra - There was a man sitting in Lystra who was unable to use his feet. He had been lame from his mother’s womb, and had never walked.

9.verse: He heard Paul speaking. When Paul looked hard at him, and saw that he had faith to be made well,

10.verse: he said with a loud voice, ‘Stand up straight on your feet!’ Up he jumped, and walked about.

11.verse: When the crowds saw what Paul had done, they shouted loudly in the Lycaonian language, ‘The gods have come down to us in human form!’

12.verse: They called Barnabas ‘Zeus’, and Paul, because he was the main speaker, ‘Hermes’.

13.verse: The priest of Zeus, whose temple was just outside the city, brought oxen and garlands to the city gates. There was a crowd with him, and he was all ready to offer sacrifice.

14.verse: But when the apostles, Paul and Barnabas, heard of it, they tore their clothes and rushed into the crowd.

15.verse: ‘Men, men,’ they shouted, ‘what on earth are you doing? We are just ordinary humans, with the same nature as you, and we are bringing you the wonderful message that you should turn away from these foolish things to the living God, the one who made heaven and earth and the sea and everything in them.

16.verse: In earlier generations he allowed all the nations to go their own ways,

17.verse: but even then he didn’t leave himself without witness. He has done you good, giving you rain from heaven and times of fruitfulness, filling your bodies with food and your hearts with gladness.’

18.verse: Even by saying this, they only just restrained the crowds from offering them sacrifice.

19.verse: But some Jews arrived from Antioch and Iconium, and persuaded the crowds to stone Paul. They dragged him outside the city, thinking he was dead.

20.verse: The disciples gathered round him, however, and he got up and went into the city. The next day he and Barnabas went off to Derbe.

21.verse: Opening the Door of Faith - They preached in Derbe, and made many disciples. Then they returned to Lystra, Iconium and Antioch,

22.verse: strengthening the hearts of the disciples, and urging them to remain in the faith. They warned them that getting into God’s kingdom would mean going through considerable suffering.

23.verse: In every church they appointed elders by laying hands on them. They fasted, prayed, and commended them to the Lord in whom they had believed.

24.verse: They went through Pisidia and came to Pamphylia;

25.verse: and when they had spoken the word in Perga they went down to Attalia.

26.verse: From there they sailed to Antioch, which was where they had been commended to God’s grace for the work which they had accomplished.

27.verse: Once there, they called the church together, and told them all the things which God had done with them, and how he had opened a door of faith for the Gentiles.

28.verse: They stayed there a long time with the disciples.

1.verse: Is Circumcision Necessary? - Some people came from Judaea to Antioch and, on arrival, began to teach the Christians that they could not be saved unless they were circumcised according to the custom of Moses.

2.verse: This caused considerable uproar and dispute between them and Paul and Barnabas, and the church decided to send Paul and Barnabas, and some others from their fellowship, to the apostles and elders in Jerusalem, to try to sort out the problem.

3.verse: So they were sent off by the church. They travelled through Phoenicia and Samaria, telling people as they went about the conversion of the Gentiles. They brought great joy to the Christian communities.

4.verse: When they arrived in Jerusalem they were welcomed by the church, the apostles and the elders, and they told them all the things that God had done with them.

5.verse: But some believers from the party of the Pharisees stood up. ‘They must be circumcised,’ they said, ‘and you must tell them to keep the law of Moses.’

6.verse: The apostles and elders gathered together to see what to do about this matter.

7.verse: After considerable argument, Peter got up. ‘My brothers,’ he said, ‘you know that from our early days together God chose that it should be from my mouth that the Gentiles should hear the word of the gospel and believe.

8.verse: And God, who knows the heart, bore them witness, by giving them the holy spirit just as he did to us.

9.verse: He made no distinction between us and them, but he purified their hearts through faith.

10.verse: So now, why are you putting God to the test, by placing a yoke on the disciples’ neck which neither we nor our ancestors have been able to bear?

11.verse: Rather, we believe that it is by the grace of the Lord Jesus that we shall be saved, just like them.’

12.verse: The Judgment of James - The whole company was silent, and listened to Barnabas and Paul describing the signs and wonders which God had done through them among the Gentiles.

13.verse: After they had finished, James replied. ‘My dear brothers,’ he said, ‘listen to me.

14.verse: Symeon has explained how, at the beginning, God graciously favoured the Gentiles, to take from them a people for his own name.

15.verse: This, indeed, is in accordance with the words of the prophets, which say,

16.verse: After this I will return, and will rebuild the tabernacle of David which had collapsed, and I will build the ruins again, and set them straight,

17.verse: so that the rest of the human race may seek the Lord, and all the nations upon whom my name has been called. Thus says the Lord, who has made these things

18.verse: known from of old.

19.verse: ‘Therefore this is my judgment: we should not cause extra difficulties for those of the Gentiles who have turned to God.

20.verse: Rather, we should send them a message, warning them to keep away from things that have been polluted by idols, from fornication, from what has been strangled, and from blood.

21.verse: Moses, after all, has from ancient times had people proclaiming him from city to city, since he is read in the synagogues sabbath after sabbath.’

22.verse: The Letter to the Churches - Then the apostles and elders, with the whole assembly, decided to send people from their number, Judas Barsabbas and Silas (men well thought of by the Christian community) to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas.

23.verse: They sent a letter with them, which read as follows. ‘The apostles and elders send greetings to our Gentile brothers and sisters in Antioch, Syria and Cilicia.

24.verse: Since we have heard that some of our number (not, however, sent by us) have been saying things which have troubled you, causing you distress of heart,

25.verse: we resolved unanimously that it would be best to send to you men whom we have chosen, together with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,

26.verse: who have risked their lives for the name of the Messiah, the Lord Jesus.

27.verse: So we have sent Judas and Silas, and they will tell you the same things face to face.

28.verse: For it seemed good to the holy spirit and to us not to lay any burden on you beyond the following necessary things:

29.verse: that you should abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what has been strangled, and from fornication. If you keep yourselves from these, you will do well. Farewell.’

30.verse: So they went off and came down to Antioch, where they gathered the people together and presented the letter.

31.verse: When they read it, they were delighted with the message it contained.

32.verse: Judas and Silas, who were themselves prophets, said a good deal to encourage the brothers and sisters, and they gave them strength.

33.verse: When they had spent some time there, they left the family in peace and returned to those who had sent them.

34.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

35.verse: But Paul and Barnabas stayed on in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord, with many others as well.

36.verse: A Huge Row - After some days, Paul said to Barnabas, ‘Let’s go back and visit the brothers and sisters in all the various cities where we preached the word of the Lord, and see how they are doing.’

37.verse: Barnabas wanted to take John, called Mark, along with them.

38.verse: But Paul reckoned that it was not a good idea to take with them someone who had left them in Pamphylia and had not gone on with them to the rest of the work.

39.verse: There was a huge row, which resulted in them splitting up. Barnabas took Mark and sailed off for Cyprus.

40.verse: Paul chose Silas, and went off, having been commended by the church to the grace of the Lord.

41.verse: They went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.

1.verse: Timothy – and New Developments - Paul went on further, to Derbe and then Lystra. There was a disciple there by the name of Timothy, the son of a believing Jewish woman, but with a Greek father.

2.verse: The Christians in Lystra and Iconium spoke well of him.

3.verse: Paul wanted Timothy to go with them, so he took him and circumcised him because of the Jews in those regions, since they all knew that his father was Greek.

4.verse: When they went through the cities, they handed on to them the decisions which had been taken by the apostles and elders at Jerusalem, so that they could observe them.

5.verse: The churches were strengthened in faith, and grew in number every day.

6.verse: They went through the region of Phrygia and Galatia, since the holy spirit had forbidden them to speak the word in the province of Asia.

7.verse: When they came to Mysia, they tried to go into Bithynia, but the spirit of Jesus didn’t allow them to do so.

8.verse: So, passing by Mysia, they came down to Troas.

9.verse: Then a vision appeared to Paul in the night: a man from Macedonia was standing there, pleading with him, and saying, ‘Come across to Macedonia and help us!’

10.verse: When he saw the vision, at once we set about finding a way to get across to Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to preach the good news to them.

11.verse: Preaching and Prison in Philippi - So we sailed away from Troas and made a straight course to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis.

12.verse: From there we went on to Philippi, a Roman colony which is the chief city of the district of Macedonia. We stayed in this city for some days.

13.verse: On the sabbath day we went outside the gate to a place by a river where we reckoned there was a place of prayer, and there we sat down. Some women had gathered, and we spoke to them.

14.verse: There was a woman called Lydia, a godfearer, who was a seller of purple from Thyatira. The Lord opened her heart to pay attention to what Paul was saying.
